awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Automatic debridement device
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be to improve the quality of life for the estimated 38 million people in the US, and 780 million people globally, who are suffering from nail fungus (onychomycosis), a $4.5 billion global opportunity. Onychomycosis is a serious health problem without a cure and affecting quality of life. Fungal nail infections contribute to the severity of diabetic foot problems and potentially leading to tissue necrosis and ultimately lower limb amputation. Current treatments have limited efficacy, often with serious side effects; oral medications may cause liver damage, and topical antifungal drugs and lasers have low efficacy due to their limited ability to penetrate the dense and variable thickness nail plate. This project will develop an autonomous robotic debridement device to reliably, precisely, and uniformly reduce the diseased nail thickness, which can be particularly effective in combination with laser or topical treatments for improved outcomes. 

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will design, develop, and build an engineering prototype to demonstrate the feasibility of the novel conformal scan-based precise debridement treatment for onychomycosis. The technology offers precise and uniform polishing of the nail at the micron level, reducing the nail thickness down to its structural yet still safe limit. A 3D printing process will be developed for models used to validate design and demonstrate feasibility.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This Phase 1 project was to design, develop, and build an engineering prototype to demonstrate the feasibility of the novel conformal scan-based debridement treatment for Onychomycosis (nail fungus). Current fungal nail treatments have limited efficacy, often with serious side effects. Oral medications may cause liver damage, and topic antifungal drugs and lasers have low efficacy due to their limited ability to penetrate the dense and variable thickness nail plate. The patent-pending automatic debridement device provides the medical professional with a new set of capabilities, including precise and uniform polishing of the nail at the micron level, and reducing the nail thickness down to its structural yet still safe limit. This breakthrough device promises to fulfill the unmet medical need for a safe, effective, and reliable method to treat nail fungal infection for the 35 million people, in America alone, suffering from Onychomycosis.


The broader impact potential of this project will be to improve the quality of life for the millions of people around the world suffering from Onychomycosis, disrupting its $4.5 billion global market. The automatic debridement device also provides an immediate improvement of the aesthetic aspects of the abnormal nail, reducing the effect this fungus has on patients? emotional, physiological, and social health. Nail infections are an important medical concern for patients. Not only does the stand-alone condition of onychomycosis prove to be a significant problem, but the follow-on conditions that can arise from this infection make this problem even more grave. Rapha Robotics? mission is to change the common misconception that onychomycosis is a cosmetic problem that does not need to be treated and provide an effective treatment option that can be made available to everyone.


In the SBIR Phase 1 project, Rapha Robotics has developed a functioning robotic debridement prototype and 3-D printed surrogate nails with their associate foot holder. We also tested the robotic debridement system on our nail surrogates, using version 1.0 of our scan-based conformal polishing algorithm. The completion of these tasks represents the successful completion of Phase 1.


To satisfy our objectives, we designed and built an automatic debridement system prototype through a multidisciplinary approach including, mechanical design, manufacturing and assembly, electrical design and integration, firmware (embedded SW), algorithm, and software development. Initial CAD modeling of the prototype device in combination with a foot model surrogate allowed early imaged based placement and positioning tests to be performed. Initial construction of the prototype, including the electronics (stepper drivers, power supply, controller board, data acquisition board and a computer screen) allowed iterative testing on function and performance.


We developed the scan-based conformal polishing algorithm by scanning the nail using a laser distance sensor to map the nail surface and use that data to create the tool path. A script generates the programming code based on the length and width of the nail.


We created a reliable and repeatable 3D printing process for the manufacturing of 3D printed nail models, which were used to validate the design and demonstrate the feasibility of the concept. We developed two types of support for holding the 3D printed nail surrogates. The 1st type is a clamp nail holder designed to allow quick loading and unloading of nails of various widths, lengths, and thickness which is important for conducting ?design of experiment? testing on substantial number of nails and nail types. The 2nd type of holder is designed to simulate a complete foot where the nail is glued to each replaceable toe.


Iterative testing of the Mycopolisher design on the 3D printed nail surrogates and optimization of the nail debridement prototype demonstrated the technical feasibility of the scanned-based conformal polishing concept.


Outcome: We achieved our Phase I objective of successful scan-based conformal polishing of model 3D printed nails and our demonstration prototype is a key accomplishment that has allowed us to improve the system in an iterative manner and provide a marketing tool to show doctors, distributors, and potential investors to ensure product/market fit. The automatic debridement device with unique conformal polishing performs a function that the podiatrist and dermatologist cannot currently do by providing the medical professional with a new set of capabilities, including precise and uniform polishing of the nail at the micron level, and reducing the nail thickness down to its structural yet still safe limit.

 


Last Modified: 08/04/2022
Modified by: Elad Taig
